fields.Title of Contribution: <p>Towards Real-Time PFAS Detection Using the Environmental Optically Gated Transistor</p>
fields.Description/Abstract: <p><strong>Abstract: </strong>Detection of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) in the environment is hampered by the lack of fast and reliable methods of in-field detection. The currently used analytical methods, e.g., liquid chromatography tandem mass spectroscopy, are not field deployable; they are slow and costly, and they require significant sample preparation prior to analysis. A real-time sensor is needed in order to rapidly capture information about PFAS release or presence in a given location, in order to abate environmental exposure. In this work, we demonstrate a semiconductor device, the Environmental Optically Gated Transistor (ENVIR-OGT) for potential identification and quantification of PFAS in liquid samples. The ENVIR-OGT is an optically driven electrochemical sensor which combines a transistor device with signal processing and signal feature analysis to provide real-time chemical detection. Here, we present measurement results for the three PFAS: perfluorooctane, perfluoropentanoic acid (PFPeA), and perfluoropropionic acid (PFPrA). Each PFAS was measured at two concentrations (in methanol) 10 ppb and 400 ppt. The distinctive features in the electrical response of the ENVIR-OGT in the presence of each chemical indicate that it is likely this device can be used to detect many different PFAS of regulatory interest.   </p>
